Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research in Radio/Radar Astronomy and Atmospheric Sciences at Arecibo Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will support a Research Experience for Undergraduates Site at the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico, which hosts the world's largest single-aperture radio telescope. Nine undergraduates and one high-school teacher per year will perform research in two principal areas: radio astronomy, and space and atmospheric sciences. Through a wide variety of research projects, students will be exposed to topics that include pulsars, extragalactic astronomy, near-earth asteroids, the Earth's atmosphere and ionosphere, as well as gravitational waves. The will also educate its participants in cutting-edge topics and techniques through an extensive program of lectures, workshops, and site tours.

The Site will recruit from both Puerto Rico and the rest of the United States. A substantial number of its participants will be from Puerto Rico, which represents a minority community that is underrepresented in STEM fields. Numerous formal and informal cultural activities will further engender a spirit of collaboration between students from a wide variety of backgrounds. Finally, the project will strengthen the partnership between the Arecibo Observatory and the Jicamarca Radio Observatory (JRO) in Peru by sending two students to perform summer research at JRO.

This project is jointly funded by the Division of Astronomical Sciences, the Office of the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arecibo Observatory UMET REU-RET program is a very focused,  research intensive program.  It fosters the learning and training of physics major novices with the seasoned teaching and research skills of the scientists and staff of the Arecibo Observatory. Undergraduates from USA mainland arrive early June or end of May in the Island of Puerto Rico, new tropical environment for some, cultural differences and eager to learn and learn they do. Each participant through the years has presented their respective research in scientific meetings and the majority (over 85% in this REU) graduate and proceed to graduate studies in their fields in the USA or abroad in Europe.

Even beyond the scientific expectations, the Arecibo Observatory- UMET REU 2013-2016 fulfilled the PI's expectation of having participants expand their learning in new domains such as: appreciation of cultural diversity,  respect for the difference and the possibility of team work and solidarity when exploring unknows but also when walking through known areas.  Healthy collaborations developed and the science as well as the human development derived from the experience was, as evidenced by their assessments, and still is another value added for the program.  Inclusion of all our staff in relationship with the REU is another strong point in this REU as well as is the participation of faculty and scientists from neighboring universities, this expands the natural exchange between the participants. The enhancement of the research with the cultural aspects and the human development opportunities is the right combination of a program like this one.
